Education: I am a Computer Science Ph.D. candidate at Harvard University where I am quite fortunate to be advised by Leslie Valiant and Ryan Adams and to be a member of the HIPS group. My research is focused on computational neuroscience and machine learning, and the general question of how computer science can help us decipher neural computation. This includes bottom-up methods for inferring statistical patterns in large-scale neural recordings as well as top-down models of probabilistic reasoning in neural circuits.

My focus area is parallel programming with a particular interest in making it easier for developers to take advantage of multicore and multiprocessor systems.  I am interested in pursuing this goal on several fronts from patterns for parallel programming to libraries, compilers, languages and refactoring engines.  The solution will not be found in any one solution alone.

Experience: Lead a research group that applies high-performance computing, physics-based simulation, image analysis, and machine learning to structural biology in order to explain the workings of living systems and develop better medicines. Member of the Institute for Computational and Mathematical Engineering, the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Lab, Bio-X, ChEM-H, and the Biophysics and Biomedical Informatics Programs. Published 13 papers in Science, Nature, and Cell between 2015 and 2018, together with numerous experimental collaborators. In addition to academic collaborations, my group works with a number of technology and pharmaceutical companies.

Second-in-command, after founder David E. Shaw, of a hundred-person company, having joined as its first hire. Focused on high-performance computing and biomolecular simulation—in particular, developing technology that accelerates molecular dynamics simulations by orders of magnitude, and applying these simulations to the study of protein function, protein folding, and protein-drug interactions (part of a project highlighted by Science magazine as one of the top 10 scientific breakthroughs of 2010). Oversaw the group’s operations, including business development and engineering; managed substantial parts of the design process for Anton, a special-purpose molecular dynamics supercomputer, and Desmond, a fast molecular dynamics software package for standard computer clusters; and played a leadership role in various projects involving application of molecular dynamics simulations to proteins and ligands of biological and pharmaceutical interest.

Experience: David Jacks Professor of Education and Learning Sciences, and Director, H-STAR Institute

With Byron Reeves, founding co-director, and Keith Devlin, now Emeritus Executive Director, I co-developed the Human Sciences and Technologies Advanced Research Institute, an independent laboratory at Stanford University.  H-STAR is a crossroads for people, expertise, projects and programs that connect Stanford resources in human sciences with research and innovation in information technology (http://www.stanford.edu/dept/h-star). We also sponsor an affiliated industry program, known as Media-X (http://mediax.stanford.edu/).It was initially established by combining SCIL (see below), which I directed, and CSLI (https://www-csli.stanford.edu/), which Byron Reeves directed. H-STAR and CSLI subsequently separated as organizations.
Director of the Stanford Center for Innovations in Learning

I developed and directed the Stanford Center for Innovations in Learning (SCIL), established in 2002 as an independent center of excellence at Stanford University reporting to the Dean of Research. It was incorporated into HSTAR Institute in years subsequent. SCIL was dedicated to conducting scholarly research and related activities that advance the sciences, technologies, and practices supporting learning and teaching from early childhood through post-secondary education.  Our funding comes from a mix of government and private foundation grants, and projects with industry grants and/or gifts.   As we are dedicated to technology innovations for e-learning and other new developments for learning, education and training across the preK to higher education continuum, we are interested in new project opportunites and partnerships that could be mutually beneficial.

Silvio is an Executive Vice President and Chief Scientist of Salesforce Research as well as an Adjunct Faculty of Computer Science at Stanford University where he served as an Associate Professor with tenure until winter 2021. At Stanford he was appointed as the inaugural Mindtree Faculty Scholar in 2018 and served as a Director of the SAIL-Toyota Center for AI Research from 2016-2018.  Prior to Stanford, he was an Assistant Professor of Electrical and Computer Engineering at the University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, from 2008-2013. He earned his Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering from the California Institute of Technology in 2005 and was a Beckman Institute Fellow at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign from 2005–2008.

Dr. Savarese addresses theoretical foundations and practical applications of various AI disciplines, including machine learning, computational vision, NLP, and robotics. He has published more than 200 scientific articles in top-tier journals and conferences. He was Program Chair of the Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR) in 2020, General Chair of the 4th International Conference on 3D Vision (3DV), and an Associate Editor of IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence (PAMI) from 2016-2019.

Dr. Savarese has been the recipient of several awards, including a Best Paper Award at the IEEE International Conference on Robotics and Automation (ICRA) in 2019; Best Paper Award at the Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR) in 2018; Best Student Paper Award at CVPR 2016; a James R. Croes Medal in 2013;  an NSF Career Award in 2011; and two Google Research Awards (2020, 2010). His work has been featured in various media outlets, including the NYT, CBS, PBS, Financial Times, Quartz, ABC, BBC, Corriere Della Sera, and La Repubblica.
Dr. Savarese was a successful video game designer. His games, co-developed with his father, were published and distributed to the US, France, Russia, and Italy.
Co-founded and directed as Chief Scientist (of a large R&D team) a start up (AiBee) which focuses on transforming industry verticals using AI.

SambaNova Systems is a computing startup focused on building high-performance machine learning and big data analytics platforms based on AI Processors.

Mines.io is a venture-backed predictive analytics startup focused on financial services in emerging markets. There are 2.5B unbanked consumers around the world, most of whom have mobile phone accounts. Using sophisticated machine learning and graph algorithms to analyze mobile carrier data, Mines.io builds consumer behavior profiles that help financial institutions and mobile operators extend services to consumers. For example, Mines.io computes instant credit scores for unbanked consumers with a mobile phone number. These credit scores are used by banks to pursue growth opportunities in consumer lending, airtime lenders to extend product offerings, and credit bureaus to extend coverage.
